characters: A MAN'S SHADOWY SHAPE AHEAD, IN THE KITCHEN -

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They found me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: being POUNDED in. WHAM! WHAM! Whoever's trying to get in serious. The door shudders but doesn't give. It's state-o the-art residential protection.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I might have five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the WHRRRRR of POWER TOOLS going to work on his d These people are determined. Professional. And prepared.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'll never know how they got past security in a half-billion dollar building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleek lobby is deserted. We SEE, through the GLASS, l on the floor, the barest glimpse of the FEET of what are presumably TWO DEAD SECURITY GUARDS -- although their bod are largely hidden behind their massive curly walnut desk All the security monitors are BLACK -- the feeds clearly

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They've become sophisticated. Before they couldn't have done this. But now...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA RISES, breathlessly, in a blur, up all 80 floo of this stunning new building, coming to rest on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30's, lean and stylish, standing on the exterior ledge of multimillion-dollar terrace. New York City looms around h beneath him. His hands are outstretched. Balancing. He is calm, but fatalistic. He's clearly going to jump.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will never let them touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attention is CAUGHT by the SOUNDS of a commotion in t next apartment. He looks over, at- 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the gauzy curtains of the window, TWO MEN force A MIDDLE-AGED MAN towards the windows... there is arguing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My neighbor must've heard the noise. Opened his door to complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two MUFFLED SHOTS - the neighbor drops. The door is pound again. It doesn't give.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He bought me half a minute. I wish he hadn't. Last thoughts are self- pitying and mine are no exception: the waste. The waste of it all. I mean, how many of us ever know what it is to become... the perfect version of ourselves. I'd come that close. To having an impact on the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pounding intensifies.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now, the only thing I'd have an impact on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over the railing...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... was the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile is bitter, as we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not so long ago, this was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is walking down the street, messily eating a street falafel. His hair is longer, his clothes schlumpier, his rounder --he's out of shape. A belly bulges against his b He wears jeans and that worn-out corduroy "writer's" spor coat --the one that your girlfriend fights to give to the Salvation Army.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was a writer. Two years after my copywriting job at Dexter & Kerr came to a non-mutual end, I had, in an extraordinary burst of desperate energy, bullshitted my way into my first book contract. This was it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, slumped in his desk chair, is playing COMPUTER SCRABBLE.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now, at last, I was ready to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS: --Eddie sprawled on the couch, eating takeout watching TV, the sink in the foreground full of dishes. - Eddie shooting baskets into a toy hoop.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Gearing up, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Eddie sleeping in his bed, sacked out, the clock beside clicking to 11:59 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Getting psyched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Eddie sitting on the john, playing a game on his childh Game Boy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A few days did pass this way... maybe a few months...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Eddie at his desk. He glances at his LAND LINE. The message light is unblinkingly green. No one's called.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Friends fled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV PANS to the FOOT HIGH STACK OF UNPAID bills next the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And banks became attentive. But just in case you think nothing ever happened to me.... 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEMALE HAND slides a KEY across the counter to EDDIE. E stares in disbelief at his (now ex) girlfriend, LINDY, an attractive, real-looking girl, late 20's. She's dressed i professional suit. She looks very sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can keep this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is broadsided. Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoots him a look of almost intolerable sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was kind of under the impression you cared a little more than just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I didn't care, maybe I'd be able to stand to watch you do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm going to give 90 pages to Mark on Friday. If you could just wait, see what he says-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop. You think I don't know what you do all day? I've loved you. I know the good stuff, and I know the shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's all shit to you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one living it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think I don't know it's worse for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know I could use a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to push the key back. He cares about her, but he also "working" her sympathy, which she instantly smells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare try that shit on me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pierces Eddie with a look. Doesn't take the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- what'll work, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both almost laugh. They know each other so well. But she looks away, steeling herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see where it's going. You'll lose your apartment. And then what? You'll move in with me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with that enthusiastic invite--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --And then it'll go on this way, and I'll rag on you, and finally boot you out -- and then what? I mean, have you run the film?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She knew what was beckoning: the lower bunk in my childhood bedroom in Newark. We'd even had sex on it once. And it was a thing to be pitied and avoided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sighs. Drops the glib tone. Looks at her, finally mustering the honesty she deserves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindy. I really thought I had it in me to do something. --I wasn't getting around it, but it was fucking there. And now, I, ah... don't think it is. There. --Anything. At all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindy looks at him, clear-eyed, seeing him as he is, and loving him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what...? I'd have had you move in anyway... if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks away. Its hard for her to admit this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was me you wanted. And not Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never think about Melissa--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in Eddie's mind, in his POV, and we are seeing a LOVELY, WILLOWY BRUNETTE, wearing an undershirt, bending seductively over him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Eddie's eyes we can tell the memory is still fresh. shakes her head, looks away. It's clearly over. She gets He follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Hey, well -- wait -- you didn't tell me what happened yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see on Lindy's face that she's still vulnerably pleased that Eddie remembered to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it--?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'll have my own assistant. You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deserve it, Lindy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles weakly, breaks eye contact. No good to keep looking. It's over. Eddie makes an attempt to reach for t check, which Lindy grabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows she knows he can't pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is walking home, eying the homeless on the street, feeling his dismal future breathing down his neck.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She was right. I was almost 35. No one talks about "potential" at 35. I had missed the on-ramp. Soon I'd be sleeping in the lower bunk of my childhood bedroom... my father happy to welcome me into the challenging field of dental supply inventory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's interrupted by A VOICE - calm, amused:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie. Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERNON GANT looks him over with condescending bemusment. 30, wears an expensive suit, looks like he comes from mon

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Of all the useless relationships better forgotten and put away in mothballs, is there any more useless than... the ex-brother-in- law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! It's gotta be-- 9 years--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who's counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking him in) Hey, you!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He genially whacks the sides of Eddie's arms. Eddie halfheartedly whacks back. Vernon sizes Eddie up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Eddie, pack it on, why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie didn't need that. He's very self-conscious about hi weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sedentary job, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're still trying to write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I've got a book contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern looks half suspicious, half impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still dealing, Vernon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like I'm still dealing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sizes him up: the suit, shoes, watch, haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's get a drink. I wanna hear about this book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I should go--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't tell me you're a health nut, now. Not with that tire-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enticing invitation. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern plucks the pack of cigarettes from Eddie's upper jac pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon, one beer. Or I won't give `em back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the cigarettes just out of Eddie's reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one o'clock in the afternoon, Vern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's that ever stopped you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BARTENDER brings beers to Eddie and Vernon who sit at t bar. Eddie clearly wishes he were elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... how's Melissa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-hah. That's why you agreed to the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm making conversation, Vern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know how Melissa is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa, naked, silhouetted in the bathroom door. BACK TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How don't you know? You're her brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see her. She lives upstate now, she's got some kinda internet home sales kinda job... a couple of kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is unfathomable to Eddie. He tries to keep his voice casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa, her lovely face over a mirror, doing lines. BACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a question, Vern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon can sense his emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walked out on her, if you really want to know. But what do you care? You guys weren't even married six months, were you--? I mean, it was just a coke thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what she said--?! "A coke thing."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It unexpectedly hurts Eddie. Maybe it's just a bummer day there's a deeper wound than he knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wanna know about this book. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considering the question) How's it going... Well... I'm behind. I'm behind on my book, and it's pretty well polluting my days and nights if you really want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much have you written of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one fucking word, Vern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Creative problem, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern appraises him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have something that can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his pocket. Eddie thinks he knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no-- no, no, no-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still dealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- yeah --will you listen?! This isn't recreational. I've been doing some consulting for a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a lab in some little Yalie's basement? Give me a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is an exclusive product coming on-stream next year, they've had clinical trials, and it's FDA approved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat. Eddie bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern reaches into his jacket, produces a tiny plastic sac with his right hand, tapping something out into the palm his left. He holds this up for Eddie to see... a TINY WHI UNMARKED TABLET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern puts the little white tablet on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take it. Get you over the hump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for this, Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, they've identified these receptors in the brain that activate specific circuits, and-- you know how they say you can only access like 20 percent of your brain? Well, what this does--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon. Look at me. Do I look good? I smoke too much: my chest is sore. A fucking corpse has more energy than I do, I've got weird aches, possible lumps, rashes, maybe they're a condition, or a network of conditions. One of these days they're all going to hold hands, light up, and I'll keel over dead. My life's in the crapper, and I DON'T think it's going to take a sudden upswing into the stratosphere if I do some brand new, shiny designer DRUG!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern's phone rings. He holds up his index finger --shh! - takes the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gant. (beat, getting agitated) When. --I know, but when? (looking at his watch) Tell him we can't do that. He knows that's out of the question. We absolutely can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern is edgy. Very tense. He continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going to tell him! You tell him -- no, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns off his phone, gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking people. I'm afraid I'm going to have to leave you here, Eddie. But let's hang out again, have another beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his business card, and places it carefully n to the little white tablet on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, that's on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it, Vern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ungrateful, now. You know how much these things cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred bucks a pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pats Eddie on the shoulder and goes. Eddie is still looking at the pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which seems to be looking back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie makes his way home, a little tipsy and filled with loathing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All the way home she was back on my mind ... Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A memory -- Melissa's face as she's talking, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She'd been so smart. Smarter than anyone around her. And oh, how she loved to provoke people... 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa, sparkling, beautiful, surrounded by people, in intense conversation with a bunch of downtown types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Oh, please, you think professional women mentor one another? You think there's some mutually supportive empathetic touch-feely network of kindly pie- bakers? --Those bitches hate each other! Quick, who was the worst boss you ever had? A woman, right?! We can't delegate, we can't command -- I mean, there's a reason we're not generals--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men gasp, shocked and titillated. The women are furio Melissa smiles to herself --she's trying not to crack up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I thought, by now, she'd be curing cancer, directing movies, running for the Senate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD ON MELISSA'S LOVELY, CONFIDENT FACE as her voice fades down and Eddie's fades in.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What had happened? Her life made no sense. I mean, I could see a direct, plausible link between this Eddie, broke and buzzed at three o'clock in the afternoon, and an earlier Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --getting SPLATTERED by some ochre liquid from an offscre source.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...vomiting on his boss' desk during a presentation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNGER, THINNER EDDIE rifles through a bureau, an old in bed, sleeping, behind him --an oxygen mask on her. She clearly terminal.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... or stealing his dying Aunt's Percocet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But there was no link between my Melissa and this upstate Melissa dumped, cold-calling people from her living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An edgy neighborhood on the furthest edge of lower Manhat This block may never be gentrified.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 40 long blocks later I was "home."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs in his pocket for the keys and comes up with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a former tenement, fourth-floor walk-up. Eddie trudg up the old stairs, the tiny tiles worn away in spots, the Victorian moldings disfigured from a hundred and twenty y of paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is suddenly seized by a racking cough -- a horrible smoker's cough that makes him double over. He sounds like he's 80 years old. He finally gets it under control, gets glimpse of himself in the storefront window. He looks bad and he knows he looks bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his pocket. THE PILL sits teasingly in th palm of his hand, looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well. There was less than nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, impulsively, he swallows it. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie passes, a neighbor's door swings open. Eddie tri walking faster.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I didn't want to see anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALERIE, 26 and attractive, emerges, dressed to go out.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Especially not my landlord's nasty young wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is immediately soured at the sight of Eddie. Eddie kn what she's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, enough, okay--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell him-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve handles the rents. So feed your fucking bullshit to him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I suddenly had extra reason to get away from her. I had thoughtlessly ingested a substance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie's tirade FADES up or down, depending on when we'r hearing Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Like the rent's not low enough--!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had gotten remarkably little information from Vernon about what this drug would do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be a bike messenger and come up with that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie continues up the stairs. But she follows, getting i front of him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...What if it was a hallucinogen... oh my God... listening to her rag, if I were tripping...? I'd jump out a fucking window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALERIE'S voice fades up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Look, I'm just telling you, he's been talking about calling these people he knows from the club to muscle you out -- I've told him not to do that, but he's really pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PUSH IN on Eddie's face, into his eyes... where we see pupils contract just slightly. A flicker.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And then... I felt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is changing... springing into sharper focus.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Levels more, layers more, 3-D more... galactically more. But the same. Just the depth and beauty... of clarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There seems to be more definition, more dimension, a litt more light -- he can see more clearly. The SOUND drops ou for a moment; he can see VALERIE'S FACE, mouth contorted, continuing to heap the abuse, but there's something in he eyes that's not mean... something anxious.He looks at her with a sudden keen intelligence. And sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes go to THE BOOK BAG in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I was blind but now I see."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a gut instinct, Eddie takes a shot, pushing his words forward with a new, sharp, penetrating intimacy, articulateness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like me, and I don't blame you -- you see a schlumpy energy- sucking defeated sack of shit sponging off your husband. You're hoping I'll blow my brains out. But my existence shouldn't make you this upset. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's hit a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that's none of your-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong at school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I'm in school!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes flick down at her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who aren't don't usually carry dry, academic constipated out of print books about Dorothea Lange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you some kind of creep? Have you been following me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw the book--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can only see a corner of it. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down. She's right --only a corner of the book is visible. Eddie realizes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was true. 12 years ago. In college... 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slightly younger Eddie is flipping through the Lange bo

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...sitting on the couch of a T.A. I was trying to make, waiting for her to come back out of the bathroom... hoping she'd have a condom...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Somehow, my unconscious had served that up... a memory I'd never even recorded. Or was it there the whole time... and all I needed... was the access?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it sinks in:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Vern was right. This was no recreational drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's eyes flick to the laptop in her bag, his manner suddenly intimate, confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're writing a paper, that's not the book I'd use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who asked y-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal Berkeley has her oral history. I'd start there. Her son is still alive. You could Google him. Sons of famous people always want to dish dirt about their parents. You'd get something no one else has, and you'd've gone the extra mile, a nice little apple for the professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this speech, MUSIC COMES UP and the sound goes dow SEVERAL QUICK CUTS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Valerie's mouths are moving... she's asking questions... he's supplying answers, lots of them...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Information from the odd museum show, a half-read article, some PBS documentary, was all bubbling up to my frontal lobes, mixing itself together into a sparkling cocktail of useful information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valerie's whole posture is relaxing, the look in her eyes becoming... friendly.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She didn't have a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mirror image of Eddie's, but considerably nicer. We HEA the SOUNDS of two people -- Valerie and Eddie -- HAVING W mutually satisfying SEX from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We'd really worked on her paper, too. In 45 minutes it was a polished gem. She was pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the laptop set up, books scattered -- then, obviou abandoned for a more pleasurable pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One nice little side effect...? I stayed hard for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR female groans of pleasure. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dishevelled Eddie opens the door to his apartment. He enters, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Happy and sore, I returned home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first wide shot we've seen of it, and it hammers home: what a mess. Books scattered across the floor, dirt dishes, broken Venetian blind sashes. The nest of a slob.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... But it couldn't be my home, could it? Who would live like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: Speeded-up shots of Eddie sifting through his bo and tapes. Cleaning up the kitchen. The bathroom. Picks u books. He starts moving the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS: the living room, rapidly whipped into shape. not stylish, habitable. Final shot: he's sitting on the (repositioned) couch. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What was this drug? I couldn't stay messy on it, I hadn't had a cigarette in six hours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the pack in his hands. It looks alien.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...hadn't eaten... So. Abstemious and tidy. What was this -- a drug for people who want to get anal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up. Paces.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I wasn't high, wasn't wired --just clear. What I needed to do. And how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eye falls on his COMPUTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MONTAGE CONTINUES: Eddie flipping through research bo typing onto his keyboard, the printer printing, doing Internet searches... pages and pages spit out of the prin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, in his underwear, is sleeping soundly. He stirs, r over, cracks open an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, schlumps to the mirror, looks at his unshaven face. The penetrating gleam is no longer in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next morning, I sent a little probe down into my brain. No surge of brilliance came up to greet me. I felt thick and stupid -- a shuffling zombie without my coffee and cigarette. In short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP -- EDDIE'S UNDERWEAR is tossed at the hamper - missing it by about a foot. The underwear remain on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lies on the couch. (Already the room shows signs of being messed up again.) His eye suddenly falls on his des

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But something remained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie drops A STACK OF FRESH PAGES on the desk of MARK SUTTON. Mark looks skeptically at Eddie, then the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Words have appeared on paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Written by you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie knows he's on thin ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three pages. That's all you have to read. If you read them in the next hour, and you don't want to keep reading I'll give back the advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie standing on the street, the crowd flowing around hi He turns this way and that, clearly anxious, impatient. W to go? What to do to kill the time? 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Eddie orders a PRETZEL from a food cart. He is having dig into his pockets to come up with the change. The VEND becomes so impatient he won't give him the pretzel, and serves another customer first. Eddie looks at HIS CELL PHONE. Makes sure it's on. No call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2. Eddie sits on a stoop, slowly nibbling on his pretzel, eye glued to his phone. No call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3. Eddie tosses the finished pretzel's wrapper and SHAKES PHONE in frustration. A RING! Eddie jumps up, fumbles wit his phone just as a passing male WALL STREET SHARK pulls his phone and answers. The ring wasn't for Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie comes in, then notices something's different. His ANSWERING MACHINE has a blinking red light. Eddie clicks button, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: MARK SUTTON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Eddie... give me a call when you get in... (BEEP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second message is from Mark too.

dialogues.speaker: MARK SUTTON'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eddie, I'm 40 pages further in... call me... it's a little grandiose, but I'm still reading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third message - BEEP!

dialogues.speaker: MARK SUTTON'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, how did you do this? I'd, uh, I'd really like to -- shit, just call me the minute you get in, call. Okay? Okay. (BEEP!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie jumps up, gleeful-- he knew it! Then his smile fade Reality hits.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But how would I finish? It was "enhanced" Eddie who displayed all that brilliance. Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, holding Vern's card, buzzes the buzzer. There's no answer. Eddie buzzes again and again. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern! It's Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad time, okay--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern -- last night 90 pages just wrote themselves! I totally chucked the novel I pitched them --I suddenly SAW, Vern, how this whole societal economic class struggle -- and its solution -- didn't have to be futuristic or fictional -- it was actually ACHIEVABLE here, in our lifetime -- and I could just lay it out, like, like a manifesto, or something, like Mein Kampf except not by a crazy racist fuck! (no response, realizing) Okay, I won't talk any more about this if you let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzzer buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. And Eddie is taken aback. Vern has been beaten up. Really worked over. His lip is split, his face puffy and bruised. His right hand is bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the door open, Vern turns around and motions at E with his left hand to come in. The place is all mismatche antique furniture -- the possessions of someone who colle once, with enthusiasm, but who's letting it all go to hel Vern sits, keeping his injured arm elevated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Eddie. I guess you're interested after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That stuff's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works better if you're already smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie can't get over how bad Vernon looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Eddie wants the drug more than he wants to know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's... um... what's it called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have a street name yet, because it doesn't have a street profile. And that's the way we want it to stay. The boys in the kitchen are calling it MDT-48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The boys in the kitchen...?" Vern, that doesn't sound FDA approved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "FDA-approved," that's a laugh. Did you really believe that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stares at Vern as he pours himself a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay, so what did we have here? Some unknown, untested, possibly dangerous drug scammed out of some unidentified lab somewhere, given to me by a highly unreliable guy I hadn't seen in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want some more of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vern chuckles. He knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it. But first maybe you can do me a little favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wants to get on with it and get out of there, but V clearly has him by the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see, I'm in no shape to go out right now. Will you hop down to the dry cleaners and get my suit? And maybe pick me up a little breakfast...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sighs. Vern tosses him a set of KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plastic-wrapped clothes spin towards us...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was amazing how quickly it all slotted back into place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As two eggs are flipped, over easy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ..the dealer-client dynamic......

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here comes Eddie, carrying Vernon's suit, and greasy of breakfast...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...the easy sacrificing of dignity for the guaranteed return of a dime bag, or a gram, or in this case a little pill that was going to cost me a month's rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives at Vernon's door. He takes out the keys Vern g him, but he doesn't need them. The DOOR is AJAR. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie pushes the door open, he can see Vernon sitting, quite normally, on the couch. As he enters the room, thou he sees that the place has been RANSACKED. Destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wheels back to ask Vern what the fuck. And then see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the center of his forehead is a neat little BULLET HOL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is no tough guy, and sweat springs to his brow. He starts shaking... then, seized with horror that they might still in here, he edges to the bedroom. We hear THE POUNDING OF HEART as he peeks in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been ransacked, too. Torn to shreds, bureau drawers opened and dumped, pillows ripped open with knives. But n one is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's shaking hand can barely hold the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I... I need to report a murder. Eddie. Morgan. --Edward J. I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the phone, puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS CUTS OF: Eddie sitting. Shifting his butt in vari positions. Holding a BASEBALL BAT he's found --just in ca "they" come back.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It took them forever. And the longer I sat there, the clearer I saw... Vern had known whoever had done this. He'd opened the door.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And one guess what they'd been looking for. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, cleverly wearing kitchen gloves, is now furiously tearing through the rubble the thieves have left behind, scattered clothes, under the bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pokes quickly through the medicine cabinet -- nothi but Tylenol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits on the couch with (dead) Vern, staring at him, if a corpse could give up a secret. He looks down at VERN BREAKFAST CONTAINER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you got your last meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are lots of takeout containers around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never did like to cook...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's eye falls on VERN'S STOVE. Unlike the rest of the kitchen area, it's pristine. Unspattered. Eddie jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie opens it. The inside is as clean as the outside. We HEAR SIRENS now -- the cops are finally coming, and Eddie must rush. Eddie pulls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taped to the inside is A LARGE BROWN PADDED ENVELOPE. Slowly, Eddie pulls out the package, reaches into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is holding about TWENTY THOUSAND DOLLARS in cash. But that's not all. He reaches in again... there's something inside... Eddie's hand pulls out a LITTLE BLACK ADDRESS B But there's still something else.. he reaches in again. A now Eddie's hand pulls out A PLASTIC CONTAINER WITH AN AI LOCK SEAL... he pries the seal off... Inside are FIVE HUN OF THE LITTLE WHITE PILLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie HEARS THE THUD OF APPROACHING FEET, voices. Making decision, he quickly tucks the envelope into his jacket, jumps down from the chair... JUST AS A COP pushes through door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Eddie, spins, POINTS HIS GUN right at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie throws his arms in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heyheyhey! I'm the one that called you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits, making his statement to an overweight DETECTI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No, ex-wife's brother. I just ran into him on the street and he invited me up to, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Detective looks at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy some drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha-- No! Talk! What're you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine, what did this guy do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was -- I don't know, I heard he was sort of an antiques dealer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dealer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE ENVELOPE hidden in his jacket, burning a hol his side. Eddie tries to stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... of, uh... Viennese kind of... chairs... sort of curlicue leg kind of things--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone is ringing. The detective picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That is correct. An Edward Morgan. He's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mysteriously, the Detective hands the phone to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The victim's sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sees young, beautiful Melissa, laughing, in the sur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie can't believe it. He stares at the phone, then fina speaks into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie. You were there?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hadn't heard her voice in 10 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right before. I'd just run into him on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all so weird...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa --you don't think I had anything to do with-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, Eddie, I know that. I wish I was more surprised. He was... involved in some stuff... I better not say any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on this line, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Eddie still can't believe he's talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa... maybe... (a deep breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to... meet somewhere, or...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets it hang in the air for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, I've got to do the funeral. And God knows what else. I just... we can't meet, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... I'll see you at the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't want that - please don't... I'll call you at some point, when this is over. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Melissa's voice is wan, vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hung up. Gone. Eddie turns back to the detective wh staring intently at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something doesn't jell here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie tries not to look panicked. The cop looks up, takin the entrance of THREE newly arrested HIGH CLASS HOOKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are young. They are blond. They are wearing very sho skirts and fuck-me heels. The cop eyes them appreciativel

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I knew, when his attention wandered to something more pressing, that he was going to let me go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks down the stairs, shaken up but profoundly relieved. Even a little giddy. Then he stops.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only then did it occur to me that someone could have followed me from Vern's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks, trying to cast inconspicuous glances over hi shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this guy following him? That guy? They all look innocu They all look threatening. He has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Probably not. Hopefully not. Worth the risk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie enters, and, casting a surreptitious look around, closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cash, the address book, and the bottle of pills are a laid out on the table. Eddie sits, looking at them, reali that his life is now about to be jump-started. Yeah. Wort the risk. A smile twitches at the corner of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is walking down the street, a brisk confidence in h step, that penetrating gleam of intelligence back in his eyes. We know right away that he's on MDT.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Back on MDT, it was obvious what I should do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is being fitted for a sharp looking jacket. The cam moves to the mirror and we are suddenly (CONTINUOUS SHOT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hip, pretty girl is giving Eddie a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Vern's cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA CONTINUES TO PAN... but instead of finding him chair we are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's doing crunches, getting in shape.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...combined with an unprecedented surge of motivation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS to the mirror... but sees a reflection of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits at his computer, a salad beside him. His printer spits out page after page of manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...enabled me to finish the book in four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie puts down a thicker manila envelope on Mark's desk. Mark is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It contains ten tablets of MDT. Eddie's fingers reach in, take one.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A tablet a day... kept the torpor away. And what I could do with my day... was limitless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie surveys paintings.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I now had cultural appetites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits attentively in the audience, reading the score along with the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learned to read music in a week...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie runs, earphones on his head. We HEAR, dimly, French phrases.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE V.0.
dialogues.text: Even half-listening to any language, I became fluent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie becomes aware that there's ANOTHER RUNNER --a power looking man, gaining on him, closer behind than makes him comfortable. Eddie flicks a glance over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The only cloud was the nagging feeling I was being followed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a surge of effort, Eddie speeds up, sprinting across street just after the light changes. WHIZZING TRAFFIC cut the mysterious runner off, stops him from following. He remains, panting, at the light.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Was I? Or did MDT create paranoia?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The focal point of my existence quickly became... protecting my stash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: the plastic baggie of pills being DUCT TAPED in the top of EDDIE'S BROILER. He SLAMS the broiler closed.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Call it a homage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands there, in his new clothes, holding court. He an entirely new aura. It's commanding.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had a new, improved game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He banters flirtatiously with a BEAUTIFUL WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying that any author who's commandeered adjective status, "Orwellian, Dickensian--"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --is prosaic. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which means a prosaic author's work rests on a foundation of acclaim-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying praise and fame are unrelated to achievement, that the greatest hits CD cannot possibly contain good songs? That Shakespeare's catchiness belies mediocrity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off, shrugs, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then I'd guess you'd rather not hear about what I, personally, think could launch a thousand ships?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a finger under her chin. He means her face, of course. The woman smiles, and blushes.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fish in a barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT SHOT (LEGS ONLY) OF this regal, upscale women's pan down around her high heels and Eddie's legs between hers, pumping. A VASE shatters to the floor beside their feet, spilling its pricey orchids.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And it wasn't just women. I was, for the first time in my life, a presence... 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA circles around a European-looking crowd... tha clustered around Eddie. He's finishing a long story -in French.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course, all this seemed to work better with people I didn't know... than with people who knew me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's MOTHER and FATHER, working class schlubs, sit on floral sofa, staring at their now-dapper son, who is wavi some paperwork in their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so, Mom, your 401 K is totally mis-invested -- these guys are have done ONLY the most Pliocine era fundamental analysis and paid no attention to eye candy psychology surrounding the stock -- (realizing they're lost) Okay, remember when I explained default flops? Did any of that stick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CDS's? CDO's CBO's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His parents stare at him. They don't know what to make of of this.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I quickly returned to the unfamiliar audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sizable crowd is around Eddie, including finance types suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Sure you get a short term spike, but wouldn't that rapid expansion devalue the stock completely in two years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-dressed broker - KEVIN DOYLE - shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, there are safeguards--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against aggressive over-expansion? There aren't, because there are no safeguards in human nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's tone isn't aggressive -- it's genial, amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're wired to overreach -- you look at history, I mean, all the countries that ruled the world? Portugal? With its big, butch navy? All that's left is salt cod and cheap condos -- the Brits? Now they just sit on their dank little island, fussing over their suits. Nobody stops and thinks, hey, we're doing pretty well, we've got Poland and France, and a big Swiss bank account -- let's not invade Russia in the winter! Let's go home and pop a beer and live off the interest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd laughs. Eddie takes a swallow of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, gets it) Yeah. It'll all happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie toasts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I want in on it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin Doyle, wishing Eddie was right, clinks his glass.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My brain was just pouring this stuff out. Everything I'd ever read, heard, seen, was now organized and available --here it is, here you go..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leaves with several people. Kevin Doyle presses a c into Eddie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have a portfolio, but if you don't, I'd be very interested in working with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie politely takes his card. Smiles charmingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "I must have a portfolio." Very well -- if I must, I must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pulls out the broiler and removes the ENVELOPE OF C he's taped in there. It's much thinner.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Vern's cash was low. And it takes cash to make cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands opposite Mark's desk.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it takes cash to make cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another ELEGANT MAN is there too, Mark's boss, DUNHAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to re-negotiate my advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... sit down, we'll be discussing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, ah... I want to apologize, Eddie, if I in any way communicated a lack of faith in your abilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie smiles coolly. In control. It's Mark who's a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MARK SUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Dunham has read your pages, and we're prepared to make you what I hope will be a very exciting offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you say to ten thousand more and another forty down the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie holds there gaze, expressionless, but says nothing. After an uncomfortable moment, Dunham continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think this could be an important title, maybe one in a series. I have to say, you came out of nowhere, but the good ones always

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't going to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's not going to work? The money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, we take you very seriously as a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sounds almost regretful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I now see that writing, as a profession, is for marginalized whiners not fit for anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sutton thinks Eddie's kidding. He laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean it, look at the life. Incarceration, loneliness, burrowing down into your own psyche, increasingly insulated from any truth, because you're not in the currents of the world any more, you're rattling around inside the cage of your brain, self- cannibalizing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunham realizes he's losing Eddie, and jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think a best-selling author would disagree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, if you're good, there's some remuneration, eventually, after paperbacks, but at best your career'll be oozing along like a snail, a few thousand more copies, whoop-dee-doo, you're "developing a readership," -- for what? So you can end up in Phoenix on a Saturday night reading from your own work at some holdout indie book store to a bored audience of ten? --Half of them there for the wine and cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but if your goal is to have a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think any goal will be really achievable, Mark, until I'm sitting on a large pile of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mens' mouths open. Then shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Financial reading material covers every square inch of fl Eddie now has three monitors operating side-by-side in hi living room, all spewing forth financial information as h works the keyboard...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I would have to start very, very small... in a down market. No one was making money. But no one had MDT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands behind a DAY TRADER who's spewing out an explanation of his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got your quantitive analysis - "quants..." Algorhythms to find minute price discrepancies... you're looking at numbers only. Price and volume patterns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is staring at the screen, blocks of information for and connecting in his mind. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie now sits, riveted to his laptop, keying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed with Vern's last 800 dollars, I made 4000 in a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was too slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, differently dressed, surrounded by stacks of resea again keying away...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next day: $7,500.00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still too slow. I needed more capital...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits across from a sinister-looking young Russian i his early 30's. This is GENNADY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't see you before. And I don't fucking like you already. Why do I give you 100 thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I quintupled my money four days in a row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gennady barely glances at the papers Eddie pushes in fron him and snorts, half amused, before pushing them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you tricked their computer, you got some fix on the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie now sees that it's better not to admit that he came the money legally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gennady smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're a crook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a problem for you because--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gennady laughs for a second. Eddie's not wrong about that Gennady looks in Eddie's eyes for a moment, calculating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people all get caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't. And what if I do? You think I keep detailed records of my investors? You'll have your money back long before they figure out what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gennady just looks at Eddie, thinking it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits on a bench, waiting. Gennady appears. Hands Ed a large paper bag. Eddie reaches for it; Gennady holds it aloft for one last second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you take this... you mine. You don't pay, you know what we do? We cut you around the waist, peel your skin, pull it up over your head and tie knot in it. And you don't die from that. You suffocate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets the full picture sink in for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cubicle after cubicle of GUYS - all guys - at computers, rolling the dice on the stockmarket.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My new friend, Kevin Doyle, showed me how you could leverage two and a half times your cash at a day- trading firm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie alone in a stall. He takes TWO MDT TABLETS out of h wallet, downs them.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd been upping the dose for over a week. It seemed to cut my learning curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVERLAPPING DISSOLVES of Eddie working at a furious pace. Another trader stands behind Eddie, watching. Second shot three traders are watching. Third shot: nine traders are watching him, awed.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was instinct. But informed instinct -- instinct based on huge amounts of research, which, thanks to MDT, was conducted more rapidly and comprehensively than anyone at Lafayette Day Trading would ever know...

dialogues.speaker: TRADER BEHIND HIM
dialogues.text: Why are you buying that? The CEO just got indicted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for the big fat defense contract he bribed his way into. That's still on. Should be announced in a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trader shakes his head. How did Eddie know that?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At the end of the week my brokerage account contained... over a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As still more people drift over to where Eddie is sitting

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd heard the old metaphors about the stock market: it was a collective nervous system, a global brain, a numerical representation of the will of God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes taking in data, fingers reacting on the keyboard...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, I was jacked in, booted up - my mind was living tissue inside the greater, functioning whole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the end of the second week I had 2.6 in the bank....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie at the computer, soaking up information, making tra Kevin Doyle stands behind Eddie, flabbergasted as he watc

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The word quickly got out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts of Eddie playing back his messages:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have... 19 messages.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Four job offers... my bank, raising my line of credit... a reporter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, return my call, Mr. Morgan, this article's about you's gonna get written with or without your cooperation... (BEEP!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my new friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you stupid shit, I be there Thursday for the money, ten o'clock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie makes a jerk-off motion, crosses to his window, loo down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a MYSTERIOUS BLACK CAR just sitting at the curb, front of his building. No one gets in or out. Eddie turns back to his machine.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And finally, Kevin Doyle, trying to sound casual.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN DOYLE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Eddie, I was having drinks with a friend of mine, and... ah, you won't believe this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindy, Eddie's ex-girlfriend, is sitting across the table from Eddie. She peers at him, confused. Is this dapper stranger really her shlumpy ex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl Van Loon wants to meet you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is pleased for him, but flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not in the finance game. What can you do for Carl Van Loon? (shaking her head,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie-- I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BEAUTIFUL HOSTESS appears at Eddie's side. They have brief conversation in Italian. Lindy stares, confused, as hostess leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you speak... what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self-improvement month. Someone gave me a wake-up call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Eddie -- I felt so bad about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? It stuck, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindy eyes him, half pleased, half apprehensive. He seems different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do all this for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says I didn't? So what -- it's not getting over? Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindy looks away, blushes. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right -- boy, you are really begging for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begging for what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm proud of you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh. This is so unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm actually... more than proud. I'm a little...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie waits for her words, happily expectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other. A lot of affection flooding bac

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Of course, we started up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is making out with her on her couch.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Her place... 47.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His apartment has been seriously transformed. Of course, nothing but a renovated tenement, but there are some new furnishings, rugs, lighting-- the total effect is now one stylish prosperity. She and Eddie sit on the rug in front the coffee table, drinking expensive wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Lindy, dressed to the nines, are clearly return from a fancy party... and passionately entwined, at the p of having hot sex, driver or no driver!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Every place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands, naked, at the window, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks back over to her, looks down. She is snuggled up Eddie's pillow, looking very pretty and vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you think somebody's watching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying. He's not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you want to tell me, Eddie? Now's the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back at her, eyes unreadable. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With success comes enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Chinese proverb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No proverb. An inevitability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should sleep. Isn't your Van Loon meeting tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie nods, sighs, turns away from the window. Then stops turns pale. Is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes a step. And suddenly... He's across the room. Boom. A skip in time.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then... I found myself at the door. With no consciousness that I had moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand on a table, steadies himself. He catches look, in the mirror, of this lean, handsome, dapper shark has become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't look all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you ate something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dully the realization penetrates Eddie's fog:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It had been three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits at a table, discreetly wolfing a few appetizer Kevin Doyle arrives, looking a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, launches in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be here in ten. Now look, since we have a minute, be warned: Van Loon's mercurial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute your best friend, the next...you're a leper. And he needs direct answers... anything tentative and you've lost him forever. I think we should rehearse a few scenarios..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm eating, Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is so much quiet authority in Eddie's tone that Kev just shuts up. But a moment later, looking at the sweat o Eddie's brow, Kevin is pecking at him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You up for this? You sure? Because I've got a little bit on the line

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a toast point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brazening it out again. Because Eddie isn't sure he can p this off either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is that little stir from the hostess and staff that only mean the entrance of a very rich and powerful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The martini is put down on the table. We tilt up to CARL LOON, a young 50, no less vital and intense than the hungriest 27-year-old shark on the make. But he affects geniality. He sits; the middle-aged man with him, PIERCE, does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Eddie Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks Eddie directly in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LOON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Eddie looks at him back, directly in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medication. I'm on special medication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another beat. And Van Loon laughs. Pierce doesn't. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is in mid-spiel, Van Loon listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Yes, that's partially what I'm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pattern recognition? So that's your snake-oil? Look, if there's one thing we all understand, it's understanding itself --that's how the business works...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pattern recognition. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, not everyone can understand the patterns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin sucks in his breath. Pierce is annoyed. Van Loon is mildly amused, but not necessarily impressed. Eddie continues with his unstoppable, MDT-fueled insights:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, there's no time for human judgement anymore. You see a chance, you blink, and it's gone. We entered the age of decentralized, online decision- making, with the decisions being made by hundreds of millions of individual investors around the world, people who don't even know each other -- making a killing in less time than it takes to sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until they weren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same rules, even in a panic. It's not understanding how companies work. It's understanding how mass psychology works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have a formula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, from 12 thousand to two point eight million in ten days--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I do have a formula, Mr. Pierce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delusions of grandeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have delusions of grandeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, as we PUSH IN on Eddie's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an actual recipe for grandeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin stares in horror. Van Loon still says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie simply stands there coolly; Kevin is nervously sayi goodbye to Van Loon and Pierce, making small talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..and, oh, you know, she's on the wait list... Rosemary's pretty devastated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter went there. I'll call the school for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin blubbers with gratitude. Van Loon's car pulls up. K pumps his hand. Van Loon looks past Kevin -- to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LOON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eddie. Ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first real acknowledgement that he's taken Eddie seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Van Loon regard each other. Finally, Van Loon speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who you are, Eddie, or what your game is, but I'm sure of one thing: you don't work in this business. I'm up to my ass in investment guys, and you don't have their half-cocky, half-terrified line of bullshit. Which is not to say I like yours any better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a file, hands it to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LOON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you obviously pick your stocks in a way I haven't seen. So tell me. We're thinking of acquiring these companies. Take a few minutes. What's your take on them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Loon's limo pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie snaps the file shut, hands Van Loon back his pen flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these companies aren't the question, are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- you're upmarket energy -- what do you want with these little solar/windmill/hippie outfits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Loon's gaze is expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Unless you wanted to play both sides of the fence, control the whole energy enchilada. But these wouldn't get you there in emerging markets. You'd need...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eyes Van Loon, who is sitting up straighter. Eddie's h a nerve. He smiels, whistles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. This must be some big- ass merger you're contemplating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flicker in Van Loon's eyes. Bullseye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's really only one company with enough bling to justify a merger with Van Loon Associates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been talking to somebody-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, it's just rationalization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it like it's the simplest thing in the world. Whi to a person on MDT, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Loon grinds his teeth. Wanting to talk about it, but skittish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Hank Atwood going to go for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are either an amazing con artist or a very smart young man.
